comment.author: 78043148@N02
comment._content: I believe this is a bend of the Brisbane River at Kangaroo Point. The Customs House would be a little further along to the right of the tall building in this view.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/78043148@N02] I vote for Kangaroo Point as well! However I'm not convinced this pic was taken during the 1893 flood...probably not even high tide...the river is firmly within its normal tidal range...there's no debris in the river...the sand bank at Kangaroo Point still looks a bit like this...interesting pic though...it's taken from the cliffs above the river at New Farm by the way...looking south-west/upstream towards the city...it's a good candidate for dating...

I wonder if [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] can be lured to cast his critical gaze north.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: !!! Jeez it's difficult to find out anything much about Brisbane pre 1980 (that's when history began in Queensland...ie. when State of Origin footy started...think a new brewery started up then as well...) As usual...if you want to discover anything about Brisbane, you need to go to Sydney...and to the wonderful ANMM! Here's the AUSN Co Building in the 1893 flood www.flickr.com/photos/33147718@N05/7252607434/in/photolis... I gather the Geebung Polo Clvb now occupy the AUSN Co Building...you need a pass to gain admittance to this end of town these days, so I haven't actually physically been there to confirm this.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: www.archivessearch.qld.gov.au/Image/DigitalImageView.aspx... ...here's a fantastic QSA panorama/wide angle shot which shows Kangaroo Point during the 1893 floods...it also shows river levels at the Brisbane Customs House during the 1893 floods. espace.library.uq.edu.au/view/UQ:260490 a pic of the S. Hoffnung & Co Building during the 1893 floods

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/b-inna] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Hi all, the captioning on this image is incorrect thank you for alerting us to it. It definitely does not depict the 1893 floods and our records say the photograph was taken between 1890 and the 1930s. Thanks for your compliments quasymody, we really are blushing. :P Thank you again for all your fantastic research and thanks also to Artist-with-camera.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: It's a pity we can't quite make out the detail of buildings at the river end of Edward St...a possible date marker for this pic might be the Naval Offices building, which was built in 1901-02...someone who's familiar with the Naval Offices building might be able to tell whether it's there. For what it's worth, I can't make it out...so I'd say we're looking at pre 1901-1902. But at the end of the day, I'd say the ramshackle establishment immediately opposite on Kangaroo Point might provide the best clues re establishing a 'latest date' for this pic. I suspect this is Birley Bros' saw mill which was evidently located on the very tip of Kangaroo Point in the 1880s and 1890s......had this been Sydney, if we were lucky, the Illustrated Sydney News or the T&CJ or the Sydney Mail would at some point have despatched a 'special' who would have duly produced an illustrated newspaper article...just so that 120 years on, we'd be able to identify the sawmill from a sketch or photo, which we'd track down courtesy of the digitised newspapers...but alas Birley Bros' sawmill barely rates a mention in the Brisbane newspapers of the day...hence I'm not sure...but sawmill or not, just looking at the QSA panorama (link above...hopefully it won't expire!), I'd be surprised if it survived the 1893 flood. Here's a similar view from the SLQ collection...taken somewhat earlier bishop.slq.qld.gov.au/view/action/singleViewer.do?dvs=137... All up, my guess is this ANMM pic was taken in the period 1889-1893.
